journeys.title: Breaking Harmful Conflict Patterns
journeys.summary: Activities to help you stop the same fight from repeating and build calmer ways to disagree.

milestones.title: Your streak starts
milestones.message: You took your first step. Keep going tomorrow.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are building healthier habits in your home.

milestones.title: Journey complete
milestones.message: You finished strong. Keep practicing what works.

missions.title: Notice Your Conflict Pattern
missions.subtitle: Catch Your Default Reaction When Tension Starts.
missions.whyThisMatters: You can’t change what you don’t notice. This activity helps you catch your pattern before it takes over.

cards.title: Name Your Pattern Before It Controls You
cards.text:
Most marriages do not collapse because of one big fight.

They weaken because the same small conflict repeats until love feels unsafe.

In this session, you will identify your conflict pattern and call it by name.

When you name it early, you can stop it early.

cards.title: Conflict Pattern Check
cards.prompt: Imagine tension starts over something small. What usually happens next?
options: Pursue and withdraw. One pushes for answers, the other shuts down.
Attack and defend. One criticizes, the other explains or fights back.
Silence and distance. Hurt turns into coldness and avoidance.
Explosion cycle. Calm builds, then everything erupts.
Avoidance. We act fine, but nothing ever gets resolved.

cards.title: Map Your Last Conflict
bullets: Pick one disagreement from the last 14 days.
Write what started it. Not the topic, the real trigger.
Write what you did next. Tone, words, body language.
Write what your spouse did next.
Circle the most painful part. What did you feel underneath. Fear, rejection, disrespect, loneliness, failure.
Now write one sentence you wish you said instead. Example: I felt unheard. I want us to talk calmly.

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Conflict is rarely about the topic.

It is about what the topic means.

Anger often hides fear.

Silence often hides pain.

If you only fight the topic, the cycle repeats.

If you name the cycle, you gain power over it.

Scripture anchor: Come to Jesus when you are weary. (Matthew 11:28-30)

cards.title: Faith Anchor for Your Next Disagreement
bullets: Before you respond, whisper this quietly or in your heart.
This is my spouse, not my enemy.
Then ask one question instead of accusing.
What are you feeling right now?
This simple shift lowers emotional tension and restores dignity.

completionCard.title: You caught it early
completionCard.message: Noticing your pattern is the first win.

missions.title: Hear What Is Under the Words
missions.subtitle: Speak Without Attacking Your Spouse’s Character.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Words like “always” and “never” turn one issue into a personal attack.

Removing them lowers the heat fast.

cards.title: Hear What Is Under the Words
cards.text:
Many couples argue about facts, but they are reacting to feelings.

In this session, you will learn to identify what you and your spouse are really feeling when conflict starts.

This reduces misinterpretation and softens tension.

cards.title: Under the Words
cards.prompt: When your spouse complains, what do you usually hear?
options: Criticism. They do not appreciate me.
Control. They want to change me.
Disrespect. They do not value me.

cards.title: Translate the Message
bullets: Think of a recent complaint your spouse made.
Write what they said word for word.
Now write what they might have meant underneath.
Example: You never help. Meaning. I feel alone and overwhelmed.
Write what you felt underneath your reaction. Example: I felt accused and unappreciated. Now write one softer response you can try next time. Example: I hear you. I do not want you to feel alone. Let

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Most conflict is a request for safety, respect, or connection.

If you respond to the feeling, the fight reduces.

If you respond only to the words, the cycle continues.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse This Week
bullets: Pick one calm moment.
Ask each other this question.
When we fight, what do you feel underneath your reaction?
Listen without correcting.
End with one sentence each. I understand you better now.

completionCard.title: You kept it fair
completionCard.message: You addressed the issue without attacking your spouse.

missions.title: Talk About One Issue Only
missions.subtitle: Keep the Conversation Safe by Staying on One Topic.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many fights explode because one issue becomes five issues.

One issue keeps your talk clear.

cards.title: Call a Pause Before Damage
cards.text:
Most hurtful words are said when emotions are high.

In this session, you will build a pause rule that protects your marriage during tension.

This is not avoidance. This is maturity.

cards.title: Pause Check
cards.prompt: When conflict escalates, what usually happens?
options: We keep talking and it gets worse.
We say hurtful words we regret.
We both go silent for hours.

cards.title: Create Your Pause Rule
bullets: Write this sentence in your notes.
I need a short pause so we do not hurt each other. I will return in 20 minutes.
Pick a time limit that is realistic. 10, 20, or 30 minutes.
Pick what you will do during the pause.
Examples: Breathe. Pray. Walk. Drink water. Write what you feel.
Pick what you will not do during the pause. Examples: Silent punishment. Messaging other people. Rehearsing insults. If your spouse is willing, agree on the pause rule together.

cards.title: A Common Pattern
cards.text:
A pause saves you from emotional damage.

It is easier to return calm than to recover from words that cut deep.

A mature couple learns how to stop escalation early.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: During the pause, pray one short prayer.
Lord, help me speak with wisdom and self control. Amen.
Then return and start with one sentence.
I want peace between us. Let us talk calmly.

completionCard.title: You kept it simple
completionCard.message: One topic made the talk safer and clearer.

missions.title: Take a Break the Right Way
missions.subtitle: Step Away Without Disappearing or Punishing.
missions.whyThisMatters:
A break can calm you down, but disappearing makes things worse.

This activity teaches a safe break.

cards.title: Replace Accusation with Request
cards.text:
Accusations trigger defensiveness.

Requests invite cooperation.

In this session, you will learn to turn one accusation into a clear request that your spouse can actually respond to.

cards.title: Language Check
cards.prompt: Which accusation shows up most in your marriage?
options: You always make it about you.
You are just like your mother or father.

cards.title: Rewrite It
bullets: Pick one accusation from the list or write your own.
Write it exactly as you normally say it.
Now rewrite it as a request using this format.
When this happens, I feel ______. I need ______. Can we ______?
Example: When you walk away mid talk, I feel dismissed. I need you to stay. Can we finish this in 10 minutes? Practice saying your request out loud once. Use it in your next disagreement.

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Many spouses are not resisting you.

They are resisting your tone.

When you speak with respect, you give your spouse room to respond.

Respect is strength.

Scripture anchor: The Lord is close to the brokenhearted. (Psalm 34:18)

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse
bullets: Ask your spouse to do this with you for 5 minutes.
Each of you rewrite one accusation into a request.
Then read it to each other without arguing.
End with one sentence. I can work with that request.

completionCard.title: You returned
completionCard.message: You calmed down and came back. That builds trust.

missions.title: Own Your Part
missions.subtitle: Say One Sentence That Admits Your Part—no Excuses.
missions.whyThisMatters: Owning your part stops power struggles and opens the door to peace.

cards.title: Restore Quickly After Conflict
cards.text:
Conflict is normal.

Distance is dangerous.

In this session, you will learn how to reconnect after a disagreement without pretending it did not happen.

This protects friendship and prevents bitterness.

cards.title: After Conflict Check
cards.prompt: After conflict, what usually happens in your marriage?
options: We ignore it and move on.
We stay cold for hours or days.
One person apologizes, the other stays silent.
We blame and reopen the fight.
We reconnect well and move forward.

cards.title: The Reconnection Script
bullets: Use this script after your next disagreement.
I do not want distance between us.
I am sorry for my part. My part was ______.
What I meant was ______.
What I need from you is ______.
I love you and I am committed to us. If your spouse responds, listen and do not defend. End with a small reconnection. Hug, prayer, or a calm meal.

cards.title: A Common Pattern
cards.text:
Many couples do not break because of conflict.

They break because of unresolved distance.

Quick reconnection restores safety.

It tells your spouse, we are still on the same team.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray together for 30 seconds after conflict if possible.
Lord, help us love with patience and respect. Amen.
If your spouse is not ready, pray it quietly and keep your tone gentle.

completionCard.title: You chose humility
completionCard.message: That one sentence lowered the heat.

missions.title: Replace Blame with a Need
missions.subtitle: Say What You Need Instead of What Your Spouse Did Wrong.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Blame makes your spouse defensive.

Needs make your message clear.

cards.title: Have the Hard Conversation
cards.text:
This mission is intense.

You will bring up one real issue you have been avoiding.

Avoidance makes problems grow.

In this session, you will speak with courage and love.

cards.title: Avoidance Check
cards.prompt: What issue do you avoid most?

cards.title: Prepare Your Conversation
bullets: Pick one issue from the list.
Write the sentence you will open with.
Example: I want us to talk about something important because I care about our marriage.
Write your one main point. Keep it simple.
Write one request you want from your spouse.
Choose a calm time and ask your spouse to sit with you for 15 minutes. During the talk, stay on the issue. Do not bring past fights. End by agreeing on one next step.

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Hard conversations are not attacks.

They are acts of protection.

A healthy marriage has truth and tenderness.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray before the conversation.
Lord, help me speak with love, truth, and humility. Amen.
Then go and talk.

completionCard.title: You became clear
completionCard.message: You asked for what you need without attacking your spouse.

missions.title: Use a Low Voice
missions.subtitle: Lower Your Voice Even if You Feel Hot Inside.
missions.whyThisMatters: A low voice reduces escalation and protects respect in your home.

cards.title: Break the Trigger Chain
cards.text:
Most conflict has a chain.

Trigger, reaction, escalation, regret.

In this session, you will break the chain at the first link.

cards.title: Trigger Chain Check
cards.prompt: What is the first link in your conflict chain?
options: Tone. The way it is said.
Timing. It starts when one person is tired.

cards.title: Your First Link Response
bullets: Pick the first link from the list.
Write what you normally do at that moment.
Now write the new response you will practice.
Example: If tone triggers me, I will say, I want to hear you, please lower your voice.
Example: If timing is wrong, I will say, Can we talk after dinner when we are calm. Practice your sentence once out loud. Use it the next time the trigger shows up.

cards.title: What This Looks Like in Real Life
cards.text:
Tomi and Nneka kept fighting about chores.

But the real trigger was tone.

Nneka would speak sharply, Tomi would react, then both would explode.

The day they changed, Tomi said calmly, I want to hear you. Please lower your voice.

It felt small, but it stopped the chain.

In the next mission, you will learn how to speak your deeper need without blame.

Scripture anchor: A gentle answer turns away anger. (Proverbs 15:1:

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse
bullets: Share your first link with your spouse in a calm moment.
Say. When this happens, I get triggered.
Then ask. What is your first link too?
Do not argue. Just listen.
This builds awareness and reduces surprises.

completionCard.title: You kept your respect
completionCard.message: Your low voice protected the conversation.

missions.title: Finish the Conversation
missions.subtitle: Don’t Leave Things Hanging for Days.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Leaving fights unfinished creates anxiety and distance.

Finishing the talk builds safety.

cards.title: Speak the Deeper Need
cards.text:
Most fights are not about the surface issue.

They are about deeper needs like respect, safety, closeness, and support.

In this session, you will practice naming your deeper need without blame.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Need Check
cards.prompt: Which deeper need is most often missing when you fight?

cards.title: Use This Sentence
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one need from the list.
Write this sentence.
When we fight about ______, what I really need is ______.
Example: When we fight about money, what I really need is partnership and honesty.
Say it to your spouse in a calm moment, not during a fight. Ask your spouse. What do you need most when we fight? Write their answer without correcting it.

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Needs are not weakness.

They are how love is built.

When you speak your need with humility, your spouse can respond with love.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pray together for 30 seconds if possible.
Lord, teach us how to love each other well. Amen.
Then share one need each.

completionCard.title: You closed the loop
completionCard.message: You replaced tension with a clear next step.

missions.title: Reconnect the Same Day
missions.subtitle: Don’t Carry Tension into Tomorrow.
missions.whyThisMatters: Same-day reconnection keeps your marriage safe even when issues aren’t fully solved.

cards.title: Agree on One New Rule
cards.text:
A pattern only changes when you replace it with a new agreement.

Today you and your spouse will agree on one new rule for conflict.

This is how growth becomes permanent.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Rule Check
cards.prompt: Which rule would strengthen your marriage most?
options: No walking away without a return time.
No discussing serious issues late at night.

cards.title: Set the Rule Together
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one rule from the list.
Sit with your spouse and agree on it.
Write it down in one sentence.
Example: If we need space, we return within 30 minutes.
Decide the consequence. Example: If we break the rule, we pause and reset. Put the rule somewhere visible. Notes app, fridge, journal. Follow it for 7 days.

cards.title: A Common Pattern
cards.text:
Many couples want change, but they never create agreements.

Agreements reduce chaos.

One rule practiced consistently can change the atmosphere of your home.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pray one short prayer together.
Lord, help us keep this rule with humility. Amen.
Then commit to it.

completionCard.title: You chose peace
completionCard.message: That small reconnection protects your home.

missions.title: Pick Your New Pattern
missions.subtitle: Choose One New Habit for Your Next 7 Days.
missions.whyThisMatters:
A one-time win feels good.

A habit changes your home.

cards.title: Write Your Peace Plan
cards.text:
This is your final mission.

A healthy marriage has a plan for conflict.

In this session, you will write your peace plan and commit to it.

This becomes your reset when emotions rise.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Peace Plan Check
cards.prompt: What is the biggest thing you want to change about conflict in your marriage?
options: I want less shouting and harsh words.
I want us to talk without shutting down.
I want quicker reconnection after fights.
I want more respect during conflict.
I want us to feel like a team again.

cards.title: Write Your Peace Plan
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Write 5 lines. Keep them simple.
When conflict starts, we will name the pattern and slow down.
We will use the pause rule instead of escalation.
We will speak requests, not accusations.
We will reconnect within 24 hours. 5. We will pray for wisdom and keep dignity. Now add one personal line for your marriage. Example: We will not let small issues become big wars. Save this plan an

cards.title: A Helpful Truth
cards.text:
Peace is not the absence of conflict.

Peace is how you handle conflict.

Your home can become safe again through practice and grace.

Scripture anchor: Two are better than one. (Ecclesiastes 4:9-10)

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pray this once.
Lord, make our home a place of peace, respect, and love. Amen.
Then thank your spouse for trying.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You are building calmer habits that last.

journeys.title: Recovering After Hurt or Betrayal
journeys.summary: Serious activities to help you face what happened, speak with honesty, and rebuild safety step by step.

milestones.title: You chose truth
milestones.message: You are becoming a safe place again—one honest step at a time.

milestones.title: You are rebuilding safety
milestones.message: Your spouse is seeing consistency, not excuses.

milestones.title: You stayed consistent
milestones.message: You finished strong. Keep being trustworthy in the small things.

missions.title: Name the Hurt Clearly
missions.subtitle: Acknowledge Your Spouse’s Pain Without Excuses.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Healing can’t start until the hurt is named plainly.

This activity starts that process with honesty.

cards.title: Name the Hurt Clearly
cards.text:
Healing cannot start when the hurt is vague.

Many couples try to move on, but the wound stays open because it was never named honestly.

In this session, you will name the hurt clearly, without blame and without excuses.

This is the first step to rebuilding safety.

If you feel emotionally unsafe or close to separation, this journey will help you slow down and choose wise next steps.

cards.title: Hurt Check
cards.prompt: Which kind of hurt is most present in your marriage right now?
options: Emotional neglect. Feeling unseen or unimportant.
Harsh words. Damage from repeated disrespect.
Secrecy. Hidden messages, lies, or half truths.
Betrayal. Something that shook the foundation.
Many small hurts that have built up.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse Today
bullets: Sit together. Put phones away.
The hurt partner speaks first using this sentence.
When you did ______, I felt ______. It hurt because ______.
The listening partner responds with only three lines.
I hear you.
You did not deserve that. I am sorry for my part. Do not explain. Do not defend. Just acknowledge. Switch roles if needed and repeat once.

cards.title: Safety First
cards.text:
When someone is hurt, explanations feel like excuses.

The fastest way to rebuild safety is simple.

Own it.

Name it. Validate it.

Clarity creates healing space.

Scripture anchor: God does not reject you.

There is no condemnation in Christ. (Romans 8:1:

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, give us humility to speak truth and grace to listen. Heal what was damaged between us and teach us how to love again.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You acknowledged the pain
completionCard.message: That honesty is the first step toward safety.

missions.title: Listen to the Impact
missions.subtitle: Let Your Spouse Describe How It Affected Them.
missions.whyThisMatters:
When your spouse feels heard, their heart softens.

This activity is about listening, not defending.

cards.title: Clarify What Was Broken
cards.text:
Healing is hard when you are unsure what exactly was violated.

In this session, you will define what was broken, so both of you know what needs to be rebuilt.

This prevents repeating the same confusion.

cards.title: Broken Point
cards.prompt: What was the biggest thing that was broken by the hurt?
options: Trust. I cannot believe their words.
Priority. I feel replaced or neglected.

cards.title: Write the Broken Agreement
bullets: Sit together if possible.
The hurt partner writes: I feel broken because ______.
The responsible partner writes: I broke this by ______.
Now write the agreement that must be restored.
Example: We do not keep secrets. We are transparent. Agree on one sentence that defines the new standard. Save it. This becomes your rebuilding point.

cards.title: Clarity Stops Chaos
cards.text:
Many couples fight because they never define what healing requires.

When the standard is clear, the work becomes clear.

Clarity reduces fear.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray this once.
Lord, bring truth, humility, and healing into our home. Amen.
Then read your new standard out loud together.

completionCard.title: You stayed open
completionCard.message: Listening without defense builds trust.

missions.title: Apologize Without Conditions
missions.subtitle: Say Sorry Without “but.”
missions.whyThisMatters:
A real apology takes responsibility.

A conditional apology reopens the wound.

cards.title: Set the New Safety Rules
cards.text:
After hurt, love needs boundaries.

Boundaries are not punishment. They are protection.

In this session, you will set two safety rules that help trust rebuild.

cards.title: Safety Rule Check
cards.prompt: Which safety rule would help you feel secure?
options: Full transparency with phones and passwords.
No private conversations with risky people.
Weekly check ins about feelings and triggers.
Clear accountability with a trusted mentor.

cards.title: Agree on Two Rules
bullets: Choose two rules from the list.
Write them clearly.
Write the time frame. Example: For the next 90 days.
The responsible partner says: I will do this to restore trust. The hurt partner says: I will acknowledge progress when I see it. Put the rules somewhere you both can see.

cards.title: Boundaries Heal
cards.text:
Trust does not return through words alone.

It returns through consistent safety.

Healthy boundaries make healing possible.

cards.title: Do This Together Tonight
bullets: Read the two rules out loud.
Ask: Is there any rule that feels unfair or unclear?
Adjust wording until you both can commit honestly.

completionCard.title: You took responsibility
completionCard.message: That is the kind of apology that heals.

missions.title: Answer One Hard Question
missions.subtitle: Answer One Question Honestly Without Anger.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Honest answers rebuild trust.

Angry answers destroy it. This activity trains calm truth.

cards.title: Ask the Questions You Avoid
cards.text:
Healing is delayed when questions are buried.

In this session, you will ask the questions you have been scared to ask.

This mission is intense, but it clears the air.

cards.title: Question Check
cards.prompt: What kind of questions are hardest for you to ask?
options: Is there more I do not know?
Do you still want this marriage?

cards.title: The 3 Question Session
bullets: Set a calm time for 20 minutes.
The hurt partner asks three questions.
The responsible partner answers with honesty, no blame, no anger.
If you need a pause, use this line: I want to answer well. Give me 10 minutes.
After answers, the hurt partner says one line: Thank you for being honest. Then both end with one sentence: What I need next is ______.

cards.title: Truth Builds Safety
cards.text:
Avoided questions become hidden fear.

When truth is spoken, the mind settles.

Honesty is the first proof of change.

Scripture anchor: Do not be anxious. Bring your needs to God. (Philippians 4:6-7)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, let truth bring healing, not destruction.

Help us face reality with humility. Amen.

completionCard.title: You chose truth
completionCard.message: Truth with calm is powerful.

missions.title: Set One Visible Change
missions.subtitle: Pick One Change Your Spouse Can See This Week.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Words don’t rebuild trust.

Consistent actions do. This activity turns talk into proof.

cards.title: Break the Cycle of Suspicion
cards.text:
After betrayal, the mind looks for danger everywhere.

Suspicion can become a cycle that keeps both partners trapped.

In this session, you will learn how to ask for reassurance without accusation.

cards.title: Suspicion Check
cards.prompt: When you feel triggered, what do you usually do?
options: I check phones or messages secretly.
I shut down and go cold.
I keep it inside and suffer quietly.

cards.title: Use This Reassurance Script
bullets: When you feel triggered, say this.
I am feeling insecure right now. I need reassurance.
Then ask one clear question.
Are we still keeping our safety rules?
The responsible partner responds with calm reassurance. Yes, and I want you to feel safe. Here is what I am doing. Do not argue. This is about safety, not winning. Practice this once together today.

cards.title: What This Looks Like in Real Life
cards.text:
Tayo noticed their heart racing whenever Sarah picked up the phone.

Instead of accusing, Tayo said, I feel triggered. I need reassurance.

Sarah showed calm transparency and reminded Tayo of the safety rules.

That moment reduced fear.

In the next mission, you will learn how to rebuild closeness without rushing.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer.
Lord, heal fear and help us rebuild trust with wisdom. Amen.
Then end with one kind touch if possible. Holding hands or a hug.

completionCard.title: You gave proof
completionCard.message: A visible change is a strong step toward safety.

missions.title: Remove Pressure
missions.subtitle: Give Your Spouse Space Without Rushing Them.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Rushing healing feels selfish.

This activity trains patience and respect.

cards.title: Rebuild Closeness Slowly
cards.text:
After hurt, intimacy can feel confusing.

Some couples rush physical closeness to feel normal. Others avoid closeness completely.

In this session, you will rebuild closeness slowly and safely.

cards.title: Closeness Check
cards.prompt: After the hurt, what has intimacy looked like?
options: We talk but we feel distant.
We rush closeness then regret it.
We want closeness but fear is in the way.

cards.title: The 15 Minute Connection
bullets: Sit together for 15 minutes, no phones.
Each person answers these two questions.
What do you miss most about us?
What do you need to feel close again?
Do not debate the answers.
End by choosing one small connection action for today. Examples: A walk. A meal together. Prayer. Sitting and talking. Do it today.

cards.title: Closeness Needs Safety
cards.text:
Trust is rebuilt through small consistent moments.

Big gestures do not replace daily safety.

Slow closeness is stronger than forced closeness.

cards.title: Do This Together
bullets: After your connection time, say one sentence each.
I appreciate you for ______.
This keeps the heart soft while trust rebuilds.

completionCard.title: You chose patience
completionCard.message: Patience is part of rebuilding trust.

missions.title: Do a 3-minute Check-in
missions.subtitle: Check in Daily Without Pressure.
missions.whyThisMatters: Short, consistent check-ins reduce anxiety and rebuild connection over time.

cards.title: Show Proof of Change
cards.text:
Words are not enough after betrayal.

The hurt partner needs visible proof.

In this session, you will define what proof looks like and start doing it consistently.

cards.title: Proof Check
cards.prompt: What kind of proof would help trust rebuild fastest?

cards.title: Create Your Proof Plan
bullets: The hurt partner writes 3 proof needs.
Example: Share your schedule. No secrecy. Weekly check in.
The responsible partner writes 3 proof actions.
Example: I will update you daily. I will keep boundaries. I will answer questions calmly.
Agree on a weekly time to review progress.
Write one sentence together: We rebuild trust through consistent proof. Start today with one proof action.

cards.title: Proof Builds Trust
cards.text:
Trust returns when the heart sees consistency.

Proof is not slavery. Proof is responsibility.

A changed person welcomes transparency.

Scripture anchor: God gives strength to the weary. (Isaiah 40:29-31)

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray together if possible.
Lord, give us grace to change and patience to heal. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You showed consistency
completionCard.message: Short check-ins build safety over time.

missions.title: Reconnect the Same Day
missions.subtitle: End the Day Without Coldness.
missions.whyThisMatters: Even in a hard season, reconnection protects your home.

cards.title: Close All Open Doors
cards.text:
Healing cannot happen while the door to betrayal stays open.

In this session, you will close every open door that could repeat the hurt.

This is serious, but necessary.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Open Door Check
cards.prompt: Which open door needs to close immediately?

cards.title: Close It Today
bullets: Pick one open door from the list.
Write the action you will take today.
Examples: Block the number. Leave the group. Delete the app. Install restrictions. Meet with accountability.
The responsible partner does the action today and shows proof.
The hurt partner responds with one sentence: Thank you for choosing us.
This builds safety through action. If the door stays open, healing will stay slow.

cards.title: No Open Doors
cards.text:
A marriage cannot heal while temptation stays nearby.

Closing doors is not punishment.

It is protection for covenant.

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, remove every trap and protect our marriage from repeating pain.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You chose peace
completionCard.message: That small step keeps the door open.

missions.title: Review Your Week of Actions
missions.subtitle: Look Back at Your Consistency Together.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Healing needs evidence over time.

Reviewing actions builds confidence.

cards.title: Your 30 Day Healing Plan
cards.text:
Healing needs structure.

Without structure, couples drift between good days and painful days.

In this session, you will set a 30 day plan for rebuilding trust and connection.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Plan Focus
cards.prompt: What should your 30 day plan focus on most?
options: All of the above in small steps.

cards.title: Set the Plan
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Choose three weekly actions for the next 30 days.
Example: Weekly check in, date night, prayer time, transparency review.
Write the day and time for each action.
Write one rule for conflict during this season.
Example: No insults. Use pause rule. Commit to reviewing the plan every week. Start this week. Healing needs consistency.

cards.title: Structure Heals
cards.text:
Pain becomes lighter when progress is consistent.

A plan turns hope into action.

Small steps done weekly can rebuild a marriage.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pray one short prayer together.
Lord, help us stay committed to healing. Amen.

completionCard.title: You stayed accountable
completionCard.message: Accountability builds trust.

missions.title: Choose Your 7-day Trust Plan
missions.subtitle: Pick One Habit That Supports Your Healing.
missions.whyThisMatters: Consistency is the bridge back to trust.

cards.title: Write Your New Covenant Promise
cards.text:
This final mission is about commitment.

You will write a new covenant promise, not just words, but a living agreement.

This is how you move from pain to purpose.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Commitment Check
cards.prompt: What do you want your spouse to believe again through your actions?
options: I will tell you the truth.

cards.title: Write the Promise Together
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Sit together and write 5 lines.
We choose truth and transparency.
We protect our marriage with boundaries.
We speak with respect even when hurt.
We reconnect quickly and refuse distance. 5. We invite God into our healing daily. Now add one personal line that fits your marriage. Read it out loud to each other. Keep it somewhere visible.

cards.title: A New Season
cards.text:
Betrayal is not the end if both hearts are committed to change.

God can restore what pain tried to destroy.

A new covenant promise is a new season.

Scripture anchor: Make every effort to keep unity through peace. (Ephesians 4:Step 3:

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, restore our marriage, renew our love, and help us walk in truth.

Amen.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You chose a plan and you are staying consistent. Keep showing up.

journeys.title: Rebuilding Trust and Reliability
journeys.summary: Practical activities to help you keep your word, communicate clearly, and become dependable again.

milestones.title: Your streak starts
milestones.message: You took your first step. Keep going tomorrow.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are building healthier habits in your home.

milestones.title: Journey complete
milestones.message: You finished strong. Keep practicing what works.

missions.title: Keep One Promise Today
missions.subtitle: Do What You Said You Would Do—fully.
missions.whyThisMatters: Trust grows when your spouse sees your words match your actions.

cards.title: Keep One Promise Today
cards.text:
Trust is rebuilt through consistency, not speeches.

Many spouses do not doubt love. They doubt reliability.

In this session, you will rebuild trust in a simple but powerful way: you will keep one promise fully and clearly.

Small follow through becomes safety.

If you feel emotionally unsafe or close to separation, this journey will help you slow down and choose wise next steps.

cards.title: Reliability Check
cards.prompt: Which area needs the most rebuilding in your marriage right now?
options: Time. I say I will be there but I come late or cancel.
Tasks. I promise to do something but it drags.
Emotional support. I say I will be present but I disappear.
Money. I promise but I do not follow through.
Words. I make commitments I do not keep.

cards.title: Choose One Promise and Complete It Today
bullets: Pick one promise you made recently, big or small.
Write it down clearly.
Write the exact deadline. Today at ______.
Complete it today without reminders.
When you finish, tell your spouse this sentence. I did what I said I would do. Then ask one question. What else would help you feel safe with me again?

cards.title: Trust Is Built in Ordinary Moments
cards.text:
Trust does not return because you feel sorry.

Trust returns when your spouse can relax again.

Keeping one promise may look small, but it is a signal.

It says: you can count on me again.

Scripture anchor: As much as depends on you, live in peace. (Romans 12:18)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, make me faithful in small things. Teach me to honor my words and love my spouse with consistency.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You followed through
completionCard.message: Your actions matched your words today.

missions.title: Be Clear About Time
missions.subtitle: Give Clear Times Instead of Vague Promises.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Vague promises cause disappointment.

Clear times reduce stress.

cards.title: Start a Consistency Streak
cards.text:
Trust grows when your spouse sees you show up repeatedly.

In this session, you will start a 7 day consistency streak in one area.

This builds confidence without pressure.

cards.title: Streak Focus
cards.prompt: Which streak would rebuild trust fastest in your home?
options: Daily check in. Ten minutes of real conversation.
Daily task streak. One household task done before asked.
Time streak. Be on time every day this week.
Transparency streak. No secrecy, no hidden habits.
Kindness streak. One act of love daily.

cards.title: Set Your 7 Day Streak
bullets: Pick one streak from the list.
Write what it looks like daily.
Example: Daily check in means 10 minutes with no phone.
Write the time you will do it each day.
Tell your spouse the streak you are starting.
Then say: You do not need to remind me. I will show up. Track it in your notes each day. At day 7, ask your spouse: Did you feel the difference?

cards.title: Consistency Is Louder Than Apology
cards.text:
Many spouses have heard sorry many times.

What heals is repeated follow through.

A streak builds a new reputation.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray this once.
Lord, help me be faithful and disciplined. Amen.
Then start your streak today.

completionCard.title: You became clear
completionCard.message: Clear timing makes your spouse feel safe.

missions.title: Update Before You’re Late
missions.subtitle:
Don’t Disappear.

Communicate Early.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Late updates feel like disrespect.

Early updates feel like care.

cards.title: Do a Trust Audit
cards.text:
Trust breaks in patterns.

In this session, you will identify the pattern that keeps damaging trust in your marriage.

This mission is intense, but it creates clarity.

cards.title: Audit Check
cards.prompt: Which pattern has weakened trust most?

cards.title: Write Your Pattern Clearly
bullets: Pick one pattern from the list.
Write three recent examples of it.
Example: Said I would do it, delayed for days.
Write the cost of the pattern.
Example: My spouse feels alone and unsafe.
Now write the replacement pattern. Example: I will commit to fewer things and complete them on time. Share your replacement pattern with your spouse tonight if possible.

cards.title: Clarity Builds Change
cards.text:
You cannot fix what you keep calling normal.

When you name the pattern, you can break it.

This is how trust starts returning.

cards.title: If Your Spouse Is Available
bullets: Ask your spouse this one question.
What is the main pattern that makes it hard to trust me?
Listen without correcting.
Say only: Thank you for telling me the truth.

completionCard.title: You protected trust
completionCard.message: You communicated early and kept your spouse informed.

missions.title: Remove One Unreliable Habit
missions.subtitle: Stop One Habit That Makes You Hard to Trust.
missions.whyThisMatters: Trust grows when you remove what keeps breaking it.

cards.title: Be Reliable with Money
cards.text:
Money issues break trust quickly.

In this session, you will bring honesty and structure to one money area.

This creates stability and peace in your home.

cards.title: Money Trust Check
cards.prompt: Which money issue affects trust most in your marriage?

cards.title: Fix One Money Trust Issue Today
bullets: Pick one issue from the list.
Write the honest truth about it.
Example: I spend without telling you when I feel stressed.
Now write one change you will start today.

Example: I will send a quick message before any unplanned spending. Create one simple agreement. Example: Purchases above ______ must be discussed. Share the agreement with your spouse and commit to i

cards.title: Financial Honesty Is Emotional Safety
cards.text:
Hidden spending creates fear.

Transparency creates partnership.

Small financial honesty moments rebuild trust quickly.

Scripture anchor: A gentle answer turns away anger. (Proverbs 15:1:

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer.
Lord, help us be wise and honest with resources. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You chose change
completionCard.message: Removing a weak point strengthens trust.

missions.title: Do One Small Follow-through Daily
missions.subtitle: Build Trust with Daily Proof.
missions.whyThisMatters: Small consistent actions rebuild trust faster than big speeches.

cards.title: Stop Breaking Time Promises
cards.text:
Many spouses feel unloved because of repeated lateness and broken timing.

In this session, you will treat time promises like covenant promises.

Time reliability is love.

cards.title: Time Check
cards.prompt: Which time issue shows up most?
options: I say I will call and I do not.
I work too long without communication.

cards.title: Pick One Time Promise and Honor It
bullets: Pick one time issue from the list.
Write one commitment for this week.
Example: I will be home by 7pm three times this week.
Set an alarm or reminder now.
Tell your spouse the exact plan.
Then follow through and update early if something changes. After you follow through, ask: Did that help you feel valued?

cards.title: What This Looks Like in Real Life
cards.text:
Amara kept coming home late and thought it was normal.

Daniel did not feel loved. Daniel felt forgotten.

The change started when Amara began to give clear updates and keep one time promise consistently.

It was not about the clock. It was about honor.

In the next mission, you will learn how to rebuild trust through daily check ins.

cards.title: If Your Spouse Is Available
bullets: Ask your spouse this question.
What time promise would make you feel most loved?
Write their answer and commit to it this week.

completionCard.title: You showed consistency
completionCard.message: Daily proof builds trust.

missions.title: Share Your Plan
missions.subtitle: Be Open About Your Day.
missions.whyThisMatters: Transparency removes suspicion and reduces stress.

cards.title: Do a Daily Trust Check in
cards.text:
Trust rebuilds through daily emotional safety.

A short check in can prevent many misunderstandings.

In this session, you will start a daily trust check in.

cards.title: Check in Style
cards.prompt: Which check in style fits your marriage most?
options: Morning. Five minutes before the day starts.
After work. A short talk in the car or kitchen.
During dinner. One daily question each.

cards.title: Use This One Question Daily
bullets: Choose a time from the list.
Ask this question daily for 7 days.
How are we today?
Then ask one follow up.
Is there anything I need to do better? Listen, do not debate. End with one sentence: I am committed to us.

cards.title: Small Check Ins Prevent Big Fights
cards.text:
Many marriages drift because no one checks in.

A daily check in keeps the heart open.

It also gives your spouse proof you care.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: If it fits your marriage, pray one short prayer together after the check in.
Lord, keep our hearts soft. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You became predictable
completionCard.message: A clear plan helps your spouse relax.

missions.title: Ask What Builds Trust for Your Spouse
missions.subtitle: Let Your Spouse Tell You What Matters Most.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Trust is personal.

This activity helps you focus on what your spouse values.

cards.title: Choose Transparency over Privacy
cards.text:
Marriage is not built on secrecy.

If your spouse has been hurt, transparency becomes a gift.

In this session, you will choose one area to be fully open and consistent.

cards.title: Transparency Check
cards.prompt: Which area needs more openness?

cards.title: One Transparency Action
bullets: Pick one area from the list.
Write one transparency action you will start today.
Example: I will not delete messages. I will answer questions calmly.
Example: I will share my schedule for the week.
Tell your spouse the action and ask: What would help you feel safe?
Do not argue their answer. Start today and repeat daily for 14 days.

cards.title: Transparency Builds Peace
cards.text:
Some spouses hide because they fear conflict.

But hiding creates more fear.

Openness may feel uncomfortable, but it rebuilds safety.

Scripture anchor: Cast your cares on God because He cares. (1 Peter 5:7)

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer.
Lord, help me walk in truth and integrity. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You listened for what matters
completionCard.message: Now you know what trust looks like to your spouse.

missions.title: Fix One Broken Expectation
missions.subtitle: Make One Clear Correction This Week.
missions.whyThisMatters: Fixing one broken expectation shows your spouse you take trust seriously.

cards.title: Create an Accountability Agreement
cards.text:
Trust grows faster when there is accountability.

In this session, you will set one accountability agreement that protects your marriage.

This is not control. It is wisdom.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Accountability Check
cards.prompt: Which accountability style would help most?
options: Trusted mentor or pastor check in.

cards.title: Set Your Agreement
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one style from the list.
Write the agreement in one sentence.
Example: We will check in every Sunday evening for 20 minutes.
Write what will be shared during the check in.
Example: Spending, feelings, schedule, temptations, progress. Commit to doing it for 30 days. Put it on your calendar now.

cards.title: Accountability Protects Covenant
cards.text:
Accountability is not punishment.

It is protection.

Healthy couples build systems that support faithfulness.

cards.title: If Your Spouse Is Available
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Sit together and agree on the exact day and time.
Then say this out loud.
We are building trust again, one week at a time.

completionCard.title: You corrected course
completionCard.message: That correction is proof you are changing.

missions.title: Do a Weekly Check-in
missions.subtitle: Review Your Reliability Together.
missions.whyThisMatters: A calm check-in prevents trust from silently eroding.

cards.title: Measure Progress, Not Perfection
cards.text:
Healing is not instant.

Your spouse needs to see progress.

In this session, you will set a simple way to measure progress so hope stays alive.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Progress Check
cards.prompt: What kind of progress would encourage your spouse most?

cards.title: The 4 Week Progress Tracker
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one progress area from the list.
Create a weekly score from 1 to 5.
1 means no improvement. 5 means strong improvement.
Each week ask your spouse: What score would you give me and why?
Do not argue the score. Ask: What would move it up by one point? Commit to that one change for the next week. Repeat for four weeks.

cards.title: Progress Keeps Hope Alive
cards.text:
Many couples give up because they cannot see progress.

A tracker makes change visible.

Visible progress rebuilds hope.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pray one short prayer.
Lord, help me grow consistently and love well. Amen.

completionCard.title: You stayed accountable
completionCard.message: Accountability rebuilds trust.

missions.title: Choose Your 7-day Habit
missions.subtitle: Pick One Habit That Makes You Dependable.
missions.whyThisMatters: Your habit will speak louder than your apology.

cards.title: Write Your Reliability Promise
cards.text:
This final mission is about commitment.

You will write a reliability promise your spouse can trust.

This is not a speech.

It is an agreement you will live.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Promise Focus
cards.prompt: Which promise would rebuild the most confidence in your marriage?
options: I will keep my word even in small things.
I will communicate early instead of disappearing.
I will be transparent without being pushed.
I will prioritize our home and our peace.
I will take responsibility without excuses.

cards.title: Write the Promise and Read It
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Write 5 lines. Keep it specific.
I will keep my word and follow through.
I will communicate early when plans change.
I will be honest and transparent.
I will show up emotionally, not only physically. 5. I will protect this marriage with consistency. Add one personal line based on your biggest weakness. Read it to your spouse tonight if possible.

cards.title: Trust Returns Through Living Proof
cards.text:
Promises are easy to say.

Consistency is harder.

When your spouse sees change repeatedly, trust returns naturally.

Scripture anchor: He heals the brokenhearted and binds wounds. (Psalm 147:Step 3:

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, help me be faithful in love, in words, and in action.

Make me reliable and trustworthy. Amen.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You built a habit of reliability. Keep it going.

journeys.title: Restoring Friendship and Emotional Connection
journeys.summary: Activities to bring back laughter, warmth, and the feeling of being on the same team again.

milestones.title: Your streak starts

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are building stronger connection in your home.

milestones.title: Journey complete
milestones.message: You showed up with love. Keep practicing.

missions.title: 15 Minutes, No Phones
missions.subtitle: Spend 15 Minutes with Your Spouse with No Phone and No Problem Talk.
missions.whyThisMatters: Friendship returns when you spend simple time together without tension or distractions.

cards.title: 15 Minutes, No Phones
cards.text:
Many couples live together but feel far apart.

Friendship fades when connection is replaced by routines, stress, and screens.

In this session, you will rebuild friendship in one simple way.

Fifteen minutes, no phones, no distractions, just presence.

cards.title: Connection Check
cards.prompt: When was the last time you and your spouse talked without distractions?
options: We talk often but it is mostly logistics.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse Today
bullets: Pick a time today when both of you can sit for 15 minutes.
Put phones away and face each other.
Use these three questions.
What has been heavy on you lately?
What is one thing I did recently that made you feel loved?
What is one thing you miss about us? Do not correct. Do not explain. Just listen. End by choosing one small enjoyable thing to do this week.

cards.title: Friendship Is Built in Small Moments
cards.text:
Many couples wait for a big holiday or a big date night.

Friendship returns through small daily moments.

Fifteen minutes of real attention can soften a whole week.

Scripture anchor: God does not reject you. There is no condemnation in Christ. (Romans 8:1:

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, bring warmth back into our friendship.

Teach us to enjoy each other again and to love with attention. Amen.

completionCard.title: You chose friendship
completionCard.message: That small time built warmth again.

missions.title: Share One Good Memory
missions.subtitle: Bring Back a Moment That Reminds You Why You Chose Each Other.
missions.whyThisMatters: Good memories soften hearts and rebuild closeness when things feel cold.

cards.title: Ask Better Questions
cards.text:
Friendship grows through curiosity.

Many couples stop asking real questions and start living on autopilot.

In this session, you will ask questions that reopen emotional connection.

cards.title: Curiosity Check
cards.prompt: What usually happens when you talk as a couple?
options: We talk about bills, chores, and schedules.
We talk, but it feels surface level.
We mostly talk when there is a problem.
We talk sometimes, but we feel distracted.
We talk deeply and feel connected.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse
bullets: Sit together for 10 minutes today.
Ask these three questions slowly.
What is something you are proud of lately?
What is one thing you wish I understood better about you?
What has been making you feel stressed recently?
Do not argue the answers. End with one sentence each: Thank you for telling me. This is how friendship stays alive.

cards.title: Curiosity Brings Closeness
cards.text:
Many couples assume they already know each other.

But people change through seasons.

Curiosity keeps love fresh.

cards.title: If It Fits Your Marriage
bullets: Pray one short prayer together.
Lord, help us understand and enjoy each other again. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You brought back warmth
completionCard.message: Memories remind your heart that love has history.

missions.title: Ask 3 Curiosity Questions
missions.subtitle: Learn Something New About Your Spouse Again.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Curiosity brings friendship back.

You can’t feel close to someone you stop knowing.

cards.title: Notice Your Spouse’s Love Language
cards.text:
Many spouses love sincerely but miss each other’s language.

In this session, you will identify what makes your spouse feel loved and practice it intentionally.

cards.title: Love Language Check
cards.prompt: What makes your spouse feel loved most often?
options: Acts. Help and support without being asked.

cards.title: Do One Love Act Today
bullets: Pick the option you believe fits your spouse best.
Write one action you will do today.
Words. Speak one sincere appreciation.
Acts. Do one helpful task quietly.
Time. Sit and talk for 15 minutes.
Touch. Offer a hug and hold for 10 seconds. Gifts. Do one small thoughtful gesture. Do it today and watch your spouse’s response.

cards.title: Love Should Be Felt
cards.text:
Good intentions are not enough.

Love becomes real when it is felt.

When you love your spouse the way they receive love, friendship strengthens quickly.

cards.title: If Your Spouse Is Available
bullets: Ask your spouse this question tonight.
What makes you feel most loved by me?
Write their answer and try it this week.

completionCard.title: You chose curiosity
completionCard.message: Curiosity is a strong way to love.

missions.title: Send a 20-second Appreciation
missions.subtitle: Appreciate Your Spouse Out Loud, Not in Your Head.
missions.whyThisMatters:
People feel loved when appreciation is spoken.

This activity makes it real.

cards.title: Return Affection to the Marriage
cards.text:
Affection is one of the first things couples stop doing when life becomes busy.

In this session, you will bring affection back intentionally.

Not for performance, but for warmth.

cards.title: Affection Check
cards.prompt: What best describes affection in your marriage right now?
options: We are affectionate only when we want sex.

cards.title: Try the 3 Touch Rule Today
bullets: initiate 3 moments of affection with no pressure.
Examples: A hug when they wake. A touch on the shoulder. Holding hands for 30 seconds.
Do not link it to sex.
Do not expect a big response.
Your goal is to restore warmth.
At the end of the day, ask your spouse: Did you feel more connected today?

cards.title: Warmth Matters
cards.text:
Affection communicates safety.

It says: I still choose you.

Even small touches can soften emotional distance.

Scripture anchor: Love is patient and kind. It does not keep a record of wrongs. (1 Corinthians 13:4-5)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, restore warmth and tenderness in our marriage.

Let love feel safe again. Amen.

completionCard.title: You spoke life
completionCard.message: Your words added strength to your marriage today.

missions.title: Do One Small Helpful Act
missions.subtitle: Serve Your Spouse in a Simple Way Today.
missions.whyThisMatters: Friendship grows when love becomes practical, not just feelings.

cards.title: Bring Back Laughter
cards.text:
Friendship is not only deep talk.

Friendship is also joy.

In this session, you will intentionally bring laughter back into your marriage.

Joy builds connection.

cards.title: Joy Check
cards.prompt: When was the last time you and your spouse laughed together?

cards.title: Do One Fun Thing Today
bullets: Choose one simple fun activity.
Watch a short comedy clip together.
Play a quick game.
Remember a funny memory and retell it.
Dance to one song in the house. Do it today for 10 minutes. End with one sentence: I miss this side of us.

cards.title: What This Looks Like in Real Life
cards.text:
Tomi and Nneka were always serious.

Bills, children, stress, constant talking about problems.

One night they watched a silly video and laughed for the first time in months.

It felt small, but it softened the room.

The next day, their conversation was lighter.

In the next mission, you will learn how to remove one habit that kills friendship.

cards.title: Quick Reflection
bullets: Write one sentence.
The joy habit I want back in this marriage is ______.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You served with love
completionCard.message: Small acts rebuild friendship fast.

missions.title: Laugh Together Once
missions.subtitle: Create One Moment of Laughter with Your Spouse.
missions.whyThisMatters: Laughter reduces stress and reminds you that you are friends, not enemies.

cards.title: Remove One Friendship Killer
cards.text:
Friendship does not only fade because of time.

It fades because of habits that drain connection.

In this session, you will identify and remove one habit that kills friendship in your marriage.

cards.title: Habit Check
cards.prompt: Which habit affects connection the most in your home?
options: Being too busy for each other.

cards.title: Remove It for 7 Days
bullets: Pick one habit from the list.
Write how it shows up in your home.
Write one change you will make for 7 days.
Example: No phones during dinner.
Example: We will talk about problems only after we connect first.
Tell your spouse the change you are making. Track it daily for 7 days. At the end, ask: Did this improve our friendship?

cards.title: Small Habits Shape Atmosphere
cards.text:
The atmosphere of your marriage is built daily.

When you remove one friendship killer, connection has room to grow.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer.
Lord, help us protect our friendship and enjoy each other again. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You brought joy
completionCard.message: Joy is part of a healthy marriage.

missions.title: Use Team Words
missions.subtitle: Replace “you Vs Me” with “we”.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Team language changes the mood in your home.

It reduces blame and builds unity.

cards.title: Practice Validation
cards.text:
Many marriages feel cold because spouses feel unheard.

Validation is a skill that restores friendship.

In this session, you will practice validating your spouse, even if you disagree.

cards.title: Validation Check
cards.prompt: What is hardest for you when your spouse shares feelings?
options: I want to fix it quickly.
I feel blamed and I defend.
I minimize it and move on.
I listen but I do not know what to say.

cards.title: Use This Validation Script
bullets: When your spouse shares something, respond with these two lines.
I understand why you feel that way.
That makes sense.
Do not add advice yet.
Ask one question.
What do you need from me right now? Try this today in one conversation. Write how your spouse responded.

cards.title: Validation Restores Warmth
cards.text:
Validation does not mean agreement.

It means you honor your spouse’s feelings.

This is friendship in action.

Scripture anchor: A gentle answer turns away anger. (Proverbs 15:1:

cards.title: Reflection
bullets: Write one sentence.
The sentence I will use more often is: I understand why you feel that way.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You chose unity
completionCard.message: Team words build team hearts.

missions.title: Plan a Simple “mini-date”
missions.subtitle: A Small Plan Can Restart Closeness.
missions.whyThisMatters: Friendship returns when you create moments on purpose.

cards.title: Create One Weekly Friendship Ritual
cards.text:
Friendship lasts when couples build rituals.

In this session, you will create one weekly ritual that keeps you connected.

This ritual becomes your protection against distance.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Ritual Check
cards.prompt: Which ritual fits your season best?
options: One shared meal with no screens.
One shared devotion and prayer time.

cards.title: Set It up Now
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one ritual from the list.
Choose the day and time.
Put it on your calendar now.
Tell your spouse: This is important to me. I want us to protect our friendship.
Keep the ritual for 4 weeks. After 4 weeks, review what improved.

cards.title: Rituals Build Safety
cards.text:
Rituals are small commitments that keep love alive.

When the week gets busy, rituals keep connection steady.

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, help us protect our friendship and keep our love warm.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You made time
completionCard.message: Time together is where friendship grows.

missions.title: Start a Talk Softly
missions.subtitle: Start One Request Without a Harsh Tone.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many fights start with tone.

A soft start keeps the door open.

cards.title: Heal One Resentment
cards.text:
Friendship cannot grow where resentment is stored.

In this session, you will name one resentment and release it in a healthy way.

This mission is intense but freeing.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Resentment Check
cards.prompt: Which resentment shows up most often?
options: I feel like I carry the home alone.
I feel like my needs do not matter.

cards.title: Name It and Release It

missions.title: Safe Touch, No Pressure

Pressure kills intimacy.

Safe touch builds it.

cards.title: Safe Touch, No Pressure
cards.text:
Intimacy grows when both spouses feel safe, wanted, and respected.

When intimacy feels pressured, many couples shut down emotionally and physically.

In this session, you will restore safe touch without pressure.

This mission is not about sex.

It is about safety.

cards.title: Intimacy Check
cards.prompt: Which struggle describes intimacy in your marriage most right now?
options: One of us wants more intimacy than the other.
We have intimacy, but it feels routine.
We are emotionally disconnected, so physical closeness is hard.
We avoid intimacy because of past hurt or conflict.
We are struggling with desire, stress, or fatigue.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse Today
bullets: Choose a calm time today. 10 minutes only.
Sit close, no phones.
Agree on one boundary. No pressure, no sexual expectation.
Then do one of these options.

Hold hands and breathe slowly for 2 minutes. Hug for 20 seconds without talking. Sit with a hand on each other’s back and pray quietly. After, each person answers one question. What made you feel safe

cards.title: Safety Creates Desire
cards.text:
Many couples think desire comes first.

But often safety comes first.

When a spouse feels emotionally safe, their body relaxes.

When they feel pressured, their body protects itself.

Scripture anchor: Be kind, tenderhearted, forgiving, as Christ forgave you. (Ephesians 4:32)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, restore safety and closeness in our marriage.

Help us love each other with patience, gentleness, and honor. Amen.

completionCard.title: You created safety
completionCard.message: Safe affection is a strong step toward closeness.

missions.title: Ask What Helps Your Spouse Feel Close
missions.subtitle: Let Your Spouse Define Closeness in Their Own Words.
missions.whyThisMatters: Intimacy grows faster when you stop guessing and start asking.

cards.title: Talk About Intimacy Without Shame
cards.text:
Many couples avoid intimacy conversations until frustration builds.

In this session, you will talk about intimacy with calm words and no shame.

This mission creates clarity and reduces guessing.

cards.title: Conversation Check
cards.prompt: What makes intimacy conversations hard for you?
options: I do not know how to say what I want.

cards.title: Do This with Your Spouse
bullets: Choose a calm time today. 15 minutes only.
Start with this sentence.
I want us to grow in intimacy, not fight about it.
Each person answers these two questions.
What helps you feel wanted?
What makes you shut down? No defending. No mocking. No jokes that hurt. End by choosing one small change to try this week. Example: More affection, less pressure, better timing, more romance.

cards.title: Clarity Reduces Tension
cards.text:
Many intimacy problems are not about desire.

They are about fear, stress, and misunderstanding.

When you talk calmly, the room becomes safer.

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, remove shame from our marriage and help us love each other with honor and joy.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You learned what matters
completionCard.message: Now you know what closeness means to your spouse.

missions.title: Share One Emotional Need
missions.subtitle: Say One Need Clearly Without Blaming.
missions.whyThisMatters: Clear needs prevent silent resentment and bring you closer.

cards.title: Rebuild Emotional Intimacy First
cards.text:
Some spouses struggle with physical closeness because emotional closeness is missing.

In this session, you will rebuild emotional intimacy in a simple way.

This is how desire becomes safe again.

cards.title: Emotional Closeness Check
cards.prompt: What weakens emotional intimacy most in your marriage?

cards.title: The 12 Minute Heart Talk
bullets: Sit together for 12 minutes, no phones.
Each person answers these prompts.
One thing I have been feeling lately is ______.
One thing I need from you this week is ______.
One thing I appreciate about you is ______.
Do not solve. Just listen and say thank you. End with one small affectionate touch. This builds safety and closeness.

cards.title: The Heart Leads the Body
cards.text:
Many spouses cannot relax physically when they feel emotionally alone.

Emotional connection often opens the door for physical intimacy.

Start with the heart.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer together if it fits your marriage.
Lord, bring us closer emotionally and physically. Amen.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You spoke clearly
completionCard.message: Clear needs build closeness faster than hints.

missions.title: Give One Respectful Compliment
missions.subtitle: Make Your Spouse Feel Wanted and Valued.
missions.whyThisMatters: Affection grows when your spouse feels seen and desired in a respectful way.

cards.title: Bring Back Romance Intentionally
cards.text:
Romance does not survive busy seasons by accident.

It must be intentional.

In this session, you will plan one romantic moment that is simple but meaningful.

cards.title: Romance Check
cards.prompt: What kind of romance would feel meaningful to your spouse?

cards.title: Plan One Romantic Moment
bullets: Pick one option from the list.
Plan one romantic moment for this week.
Examples: A meal at home with candles. A walk. A thoughtful note. A surprise snack. A short date.
Write the day and time.
Do not cancel unless it is urgent.
After it happens, ask your spouse: Did you feel loved? Romance is not luxury. It is connection.

cards.title: Real Life Example
cards.text:
Tomi stopped initiating because rejection felt heavy.

Nneka assumed Tomi no longer cared.

They reduced tension when they agreed on one rule: no pressure, but daily affection.

Small safe touch reopened warmth.

Next mission, you will learn how to talk about desire differences without shame.

Scripture anchor: Two are better than one. (Ecclesiastes 4:9-10)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, restore delight and joy in our marriage.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You built desire

missions.whyThisMatters: A simple “menu” reduces awkwardness and increases safety.

cards.title: Handle Desire Differences with Respect
cards.text:
Many couples struggle because one spouse wants intimacy more often.

This can create pressure, guilt, or resentment.

In this session, you will talk about desire differences with respect and maturity.

cards.title: Desire Difference Check
cards.prompt: What usually happens when one person wants intimacy and the other does not?
options: We handle it calmly and respectfully.

cards.title: Use This Respectful Script
bullets: Do this in a calm moment, not during tension.
The spouse who wants intimacy says.
I miss being close to you. I do not want to pressure you. Can we talk about what helps you feel ready?
The spouse who is not ready says.
I want closeness too. I need ______ to feel safe and open.

Agree on one practical change for this week. Examples: More affection, better timing, emotional connection, less stress, clearer communication. End by thanking each other for honesty. If you feel rejected

cards.title: Desire Is Not a Weapon
cards.text:
Higher desire does not mean you are selfish.

Lower desire does not mean you are cold.

Respect and safety are what keep love alive.

cards.title: Faith Anchor
bullets: Pray one short prayer if it fits your marriage.
Lord, help us love each other with patience and honor. Amen.
If you feel rejected often, write the exact sentence you wish your spouse would say after saying no.
Then share it calmly: When you say no, I need one gentle sentence so I do not feel pushed away.

completionCard.title: You made it easier

missions.title: Do a 3-minute Emotional Check-in
missions.subtitle: Reconnect Emotionally in a Simple Way.

cards.title: Heal Rejection and Shame
cards.text:
Many intimacy struggles have deep emotions underneath.

Rejection creates insecurity.
Shame creates silence.

In this session, you will name what you carry and bring it into the light.

This is not about performance. It is about safety, warmth, and mutual desire.

cards.title: Emotion Check
cards.prompt: What emotion affects intimacy most for you?

Each spouse answers: What makes me feel desired. What makes me feel pressured.
Agree on one phrase that signals pressure, and one phrase that signals desire.
Plan one night this week for affection without expectation. Kissing, cuddling, holding.
If sex happens, let it be mutual. If it does not, still end with warmth.

Pressure and fear kill intimacy.

Safety and patience revive it.

cards.title: Rebuild Attraction on Purpose
cards.text:
Attraction can fade when life becomes heavy.

But attraction can also be rebuilt.

In this session, you will take one step that rebuilds attraction and desire.

This is how you protect your marriage long term.

cards.title: Attraction Check
cards.prompt: What has reduced attraction most in your marriage?

cards.title: Choose One Attraction Builder
bullets: Pick one action you will do this week.
Compliment your spouse sincerely every day for 3 days.
Dress intentionally for your spouse once this week.
Plan one date that feels romantic, not functional.
Resolve one conflict that keeps tension in the home.
Bring back a habit you used to do when dating. Do it and observe what changes.

cards.title: What This Looks Like in Real Life
cards.text:
Sola assumed attraction was gone forever because life felt heavy.

Kemi was tired and emotionally distant.

The shift started when Sola began showing kindness daily and planning one romantic moment.

It did not fix everything overnight, but it reopened warmth.

In the next mission, you will learn how to initiate intimacy without pressure.

cards.title: If Your Spouse Is Available

What makes you feel most attracted to me?

cards.title: Initiate Without Pressure
cards.text:
Many intimacy problems come from how intimacy is initiated.

If initiation feels like demand, the other spouse shuts down.

In this session, you will learn how to initiate with gentleness and respect.

This is how you protect your marriage long term.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

This is not about performance. It is about safety, warmth, and mutual desire.

cards.title: Initiation Check
cards.prompt: What usually happens when intimacy is initiated?

bullets: For 7 days, give one daily act of affection. A hug, a kiss, a kind text, a hand squeeze.
Each day, give one compliment that is specific, not general.
Remove one turn off. Harsh tone, dirty environment, unresolved conflict, exhaustion.
Choose one turn on. Help with chores, gentle words, playful touch, prayer together.
At day 7, talk: What helped. What did not help.
Then plan the next 7 days intentionally.

cards.title: Create Your Intimacy Rhythm
cards.text:
Intimacy improves when couples stop guessing and start planning.

In this session, you will create a rhythm that feels realistic for your season.

This reduces frustration and builds anticipation.

This is how you protect your marriage long term.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Rhythm Check
cards.prompt: Which rhythm feels realistic for your current season?
options: Weekly planned date night plus intimacy time.
Two times a week with flexibility.
One time a week with more affection daily.

cards.title: Set Your Rhythm
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one option from the list.
Agree on one day or time for connection.
Agree on one rule: intimacy is not forced.
Agree on one daily affection habit.
Example: Hug every morning. Kiss before sleep. Write your rhythm in one sentence and save it. Review it weekly and adjust as needed.

cards.title: Rhythm Reduces Pressure
cards.text:
A rhythm turns intimacy into partnership.

It removes guessing and resentment.

It creates stability and hope.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Promise Focus
cards.prompt: What does your spouse need most from you to feel safe in intimacy?

I will not pressure or punish.
I will communicate desires with respect. 5. I will protect our intimacy from shame and secrecy. Add one line that fits your marriage most. Read it to your spouse this week if possible. Keep it in y

cards.title: Intimacy Is Covenant Care
cards.text:

When spouses feel safe and wanted, love becomes joyful again.
