missions.title: Say One Expectation Out Loud
missions.subtitle: Stop Expecting Your Spouse to Read Your Mind.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Silent expectations create resentment.

Clear expectations create peace.

cards.title: Name What You Expect
cards.text:
Many marriages suffer because expectations are assumed, not spoken.

Unspoken expectations become resentment.

In this session, you will name what you expect and what you need in this season.

cards.title: Expectation Check
cards.prompt: Where do unmet expectations show up most?

cards.title: Write Your Top Expectations
bullets: Write 5 expectations you carry in your heart.
Write 3 expectations you think your spouse carries.
Circle the one expectation that has caused the most resentment.
Rewrite it as a clear request.
Example: I need two evenings a week where we share chores and talk.
Save this. You will use it in the next mission.

cards.title: Expectations Must Be Spoken
cards.text:
Your spouse cannot meet needs they do not understand.

Clarity is kindness.

Clear requests reduce resentment.

Scripture anchor: God does not reject you. There is no condemnation in Christ. (Romans 8:1:

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, give us humility to communicate our needs and grace to serve each other well.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You chose clarity
completionCard.message: Clear expectations prevent silent resentment.

missions.title: Ask Your Spouse’s Expectation
missions.subtitle: Let Your Spouse Name What They Need Too.
missions.whyThisMatters: Peace grows when both of you feel heard and considered.

cards.title: Ask Your Spouse What They Need
cards.text:
Assumptions create disappointment.

In this session, you will ask your spouse what they need from you in this season.

This mission works best with your spouse present.

cards.title: Listening Check
cards.prompt: When your spouse shares needs, what do you often do?
options: I try to fix everything fast.

cards.title: The 10 Minute Expectation Talk
bullets: Sit together for 10 minutes, no phones.
Ask: What do you need from me in this season that I am not giving?
Listen fully. Do not explain.
Respond with one line: Thank you. I will work on that.
Ask: What is one thing I do that helps you?
End by agreeing on one small change for this week.

cards.title: Needs Are Not Attacks
cards.text:
A spouse sharing needs is not trying to shame you.

They are trying to stay connected.

Listening keeps the marriage soft.

cards.title: Quick Reflection
bullets: Write one sentence: My spouse needs ______ most from me right now.
Write one action you will do in the next 48 hours.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You listened well
completionCard.message: Now you know what your spouse needs from you.

missions.title: List Your Top 3 Responsibilities
missions.subtitle: Agree on Who Handles What in Your Home.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many couples fight because roles are unclear.

Clarity reduces stress.

cards.title: Divide Responsibilities Clearly
cards.text:
Many couples fight because duties are unclear.

In this session, you will list responsibilities and assign ownership.

Clarity reduces repeated arguments.

cards.title: Responsibility Tension
cards.prompt: Where is the biggest imbalance?

cards.title: The Responsibility List
bullets: Write the top 10 responsibilities in your home.
Mark who currently handles each one.
Circle the top 3 that cause the most tension.
If your spouse is available, decide who owns each one going forward.
If not, write your proposed division and share later.
Agree on one weekly check to review what is working.

cards.title: Shared Load Builds Respect
cards.text:
A spouse who feels alone will eventually feel unloved.

Shared responsibility communicates partnership.

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, help us serve each other with joy and fairness.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You made roles visible
completionCard.message: Visible roles reduce hidden resentment.

missions.title: Stop Scorekeeping for One Day
missions.subtitle: Serve Without Keeping Count.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Scorekeeping fuels bitterness.

Serving with love builds peace.

cards.title: Stop Scorekeeping for One Day
cards.text:
Scorekeeping kills love.

In this session, you will drop the mental record of who did what.

This mission resets the tone of your home.

cards.title: Scorekeeping Check
cards.prompt: When you feel overwhelmed, what do you think?
options: I do more than my spouse.
If I stop, everything will collapse.
I do not keep score often.

cards.title: Do This Today
bullets: For one day, do not mention what you have done.
Do one helpful act quietly.
When you feel the urge to complain, write it in your notes instead.
At night, tell your spouse one appreciation instead of one complaint.
Example: Thank you for what you did today.

cards.title: Appreciation Changes Atmosphere
cards.text:
Praise is not pretending.

Praise is choosing peace over pressure.

A home with appreciation becomes lighter.

Scripture anchor: Love is patient and kind. It does not keep a record of wrongs. (1 Corinthians 13:4-5)

cards.title: Reflection
bullets: Write one sentence: The score I keep most is ______.
Write one new habit: I will speak appreciation daily.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You lowered tension
completionCard.message: Removing scorekeeping protects your home.

missions.title: Make One Boundary and One Request
missions.subtitle: Say What You Can’t Do and What You Can Do.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Healthy boundaries stop burnout.

Clear requests stop resentment.

cards.title: Make One Boundary and One Request
cards.text:
Roles become unhealthy when boundaries are weak.

In this session, you will set one boundary and make one clear request.

This prevents resentment.

cards.title: Boundary Check
cards.prompt: Which boundary is most needed?

cards.title: Write It Clearly
bullets: Write one boundary: I will not ______.
Example: I will not discuss important issues when we are shouting.
Write one request: I need ______.
Example: I need us to plan chores on Sunday.
If your spouse is available, share both calmly.
Ask: Can we agree on this for 7 days?

cards.title: Boundaries Protect Love
cards.text:
A boundary is not control.

It is clarity.

Clarity keeps love safe.

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, give us wisdom to honor each other’s needs and protect our peace.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You protected your peace
completionCard.message: Boundaries and requests make marriage practical.

missions.title: Reset One Unclear Expectation
missions.subtitle: Turn a Vague Expectation into a Clear Agreement.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Vague expectations create disappointment.

Agreements create stability.

cards.title: Reset One Unclear Expectation
cards.text:
Some expectations are unfair because they were never discussed.

In this session, you will reset one unclear expectation and replace it with agreement.

cards.title: Reset Check
cards.prompt: Which expectation needs resetting?
options: How time is spent after work.

cards.title: The Reset Talk
bullets: Write the old expectation you carried.
Write why it has been hard.
Write a new fair agreement in one sentence.
If your spouse is available, share it with calm tone.
Use this line: I want us to agree, not assume.
End with one next step you will both try this week.

cards.title: Agreements Beat Assumptions
cards.text:
Assumptions create disappointment.

Agreements create teamwork.

This is how roles become healthy.

cards.title: Mini Action
bullets: Write your new agreement in your notes.
Set a reminder to review it in 7 days.
Write your answer in your notes, not in your head.

completionCard.title: You turned fog into clarity
completionCard.message: Clear actions prevent repeated conflict.

missions.title: Agree on a Decision Rule
missions.subtitle: Decide How You Make Decisions as a Couple.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many fights are really about power.

A simple rule reduces struggle.

cards.title: Agree on a Decision Rule
cards.text:
Many couples fight because decision making is unclear.

In this session, you will agree on how decisions are made in your home.

cards.title: Decision Check
cards.prompt: Which decision area causes tension?

cards.title: Pick One Rule
bullets: Choose one decision rule and agree on it.
Rule A: We do not decide alone on big issues.
Rule B: We discuss, pray, and wait 24 hours before major decisions.
Rule C: If one spouse is uncomfortable, we pause and revisit.
Write the rule in one sentence and keep it visible.
Use it the next time tension starts.

cards.title: Decision Rules Reduce Fights
cards.text:
A clear decision rule prevents power struggles.

It builds trust and respect.

Scripture anchor: Let your words be full of grace, even when you disagree. (Colossians 4:6)

cards.title: If You Are Willing
cards.text:
Lord, give us unity and wisdom in decisions.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You reduced power struggles
completionCard.message: A clear rule keeps decisions peaceful.

missions.title: Do a 2-minute Daily Check-in
missions.subtitle: Prevent Resentment with a Short Check-in.
missions.whyThisMatters: Small check-ins stop small frustrations from becoming big fights.

cards.title: Do a 2 Minute Daily Check in
cards.text:
When couples check in daily, resentment has less room to grow.

In this session, you will start a 2 minute daily check in.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Check in Time
cards.prompt: When is the best time for a short check in?

cards.title: Use This Script
bullets: Ask two questions daily for 7 days.
How are you today?
How can I support you today?
Keep it short. Two minutes.
End with one touch. A hug or hand squeeze.
Track how your home feels after 7 days.

cards.title: Small Check Ins Prevent Drift
cards.text:
Many marriages drift because no one checks in.

Two minutes a day can keep hearts connected.

cards.title: Reflection
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Write one sentence: The support my spouse needs most is ______.
Plan one act of support tomorrow.

completionCard.title: You stayed aligned
completionCard.message: Short check-ins protect your peace.

missions.title: Do a Weekly Reset
missions.subtitle: Review What Worked and What Didn’t.
missions.whyThisMatters: A weekly reset keeps small issues from piling up.

cards.title: Do a Weekly Reset Meeting
cards.text:
Healthy marriages review the week and adjust.

In this session, you will plan a weekly reset meeting that keeps expectations clear.

Your marriage deserves effort, not excuses.

cards.title: Weekly Reset Focus
cards.prompt: What should your weekly reset cover?

cards.title: Set It up
bullets: Do it today, not later.
Pick one day and time for a 20 minute reset.
Agenda: What went well? What was hard? What do we adjust?
Each person shares one appreciation.
Each person shares one request.
